pages.text: Through the $(2)Modifier Augmentation$() process, it is possible to increase the modification factors of a modifier. This is done by calibrating a modifier's tolerance circuits against a standard augmentation circuit. Unfortunately, this is a destructive process, and so the calibration circuit is lost. Any one modifier cannot be augmented beyond 100% in a given modification factor.

pages.title: Damage Augmentation
pages.text: By calibrating a modifier against a $(3)Speed Upgrade$(), it is possible to augment its effectiveness in increasing damage output. Unfortunately, this comes at a cost: energy cost is also increased as a result.

pages.title: Energy Augmentation
pages.text: By calibrating a modifier against an $(2)Energy Upgrade$(), it is possible to augment its effectiveness in decreasing energy consumption. This can also be used to counterbalance the increased energy consumption of damage modifiers.

pages.title: Heat Augmentation
pages.text: By calibrating a modifier against a $(6)Gas Upgrade$(), it is possible to augment its effectiveness in increasing heat dispersion. It may even be possible to negate overheating entirely with sufficient augmentation.
